title: Boris Johnson confronted by father of sick child over ‘destroyed’ NHS
text:
Britain's Prime Minister Boris Johnson meets members of staff during his visit to Whipps Cross University Hospital in Leytonstone, London on September 18, 2019 | Yui Mok/AFP via Getty Images Boris Johnson confronted by father of sick child over ‘destroyed’ NHS ‘Well actually there’s no press here,’ says prime minister while being followed by the press.

Boris Johnson was confronted Wednesday by the angry father of a sick child during a hospital visit who told him that "the NHS has been destroyed ... and now you come here for a press opportunity."

The clearly rattled British prime minister then, oddly considering the event was being covered by much of the British media, said: "Well actually there's no press here." His accuser then gestured to the reporters and cameras and said: "What do you mean there's no press here, who are these people?"

The angry father was Omar Salem, a Labour activist campaigning against Brexit, who took to Twitter to say that he gave Johnson "a piece of my mind about how he is running the NHS based on the experience with my 7 day old daughter, who was neglected for hours last night."

He said the team in the accident and emergency department at Whipps Cross University Hospital in London "were great but she then went for hours on the ward without seeing a doctor."

"What do you mean there's no press here, who are these people?" The father of a sick child tells Boris Johnson during a hospital visit that "the NHS has been destroyed... and now you come here for a press opportunity". pic.twitter.com/eN7L9p2fsN — Channel 4 News (@Channel4News) September 18, 2019

A spokesman for the prime minister said Salem was understandably “very distressed” and the prime minister was “not going to hide away from those circumstances when he goes on these visits, and so obviously is keen to talk to people and empathise and see what he can do to help,” the Guardian reported.
description: ‘Well actually there’s no press here,’ says prime minister while being followed by the press.
